commentBody:
I stopped watching sports on television years ago. The replay, the constant bantering between the announcers, the commercials that interfere with the game, and the fact that I'd rather be outside than listening to the nonsense mean that I don't have to listen. I watch the birds, read books, swim, bike, cook, or do something for myself. Replays slow the game down, destroy continuity, and don't the fans any favors either. All the statistics that are broadcast are meaningless too. This is for tennis, not the NFL but from what I've seen and read, it applies there too. In fact it applies to life. We are constantly being second guessed on what we do. Never do we hear from our friends, our families, or anyone, that we did the best we could with the information we had. It's as if we were supposed to know how things would turn out in advance.

Life, like sports, has to be lived forward while looking back. But what needs to be taken into account is that we don't always have the knowledge or view another person has. Perhaps we need to learn to make the calls on what we see, not the replay. It's called dealing with it unless it's such a serious infraction that revisiting it will right a wrong. Now, I think I'll go read my book.

replies.commentBody: I agree wholeheartedly with Hen3ry. I have played and enjoyed sports for 6 decades; a few yrs ago started with the sound muted; now turn off the set when a replay controversy begins. If the desire to remove the human element of referees continues, limit replays to a) on request of coach/manager, b) 2 per game.

I agree about statistics.  They compare ballplayers' single season and career stats without mentioning that the seasons are longer.  Over twenty years, a pro baseball player with 8 extra games a year has a whole extra season added to his career and a pro football player, in a 16 as opposed to a 12 game season, gets an extra season's worth of stats added in with every  three seasons they actually play.
